cases.title: The Wage Determinant
cases.briefing: We are tracking 3,000 male subjects in the Atlantic region. The objective is to isolate the variables determining income.
investigation_points: Is the relationship between Age and Wage linear, or does it degrade after 60? [cite: 37]
Does Education level guarantee a higher bracket, or is it merely a correlation? [cite: 39]
The data spans 2003-2009. We must account for the steady $10,000 inflationary drift. [cite: 38]

cases.title: The S&P Volatility
cases.briefing: Five years of daily S&P 500 movements (2001-2005). The goal is not to predict the price, but the 'Direction' (Up or Down).
investigation_points: Initial scans suggest yesterday's returns have zero correlation with today's. [cite: 90]
Standard trading strategies fail here. We need to find weak non-linear signals. [cite: 92]
Can we break the 50/50 probability barrier? (Current Target: 60% Accuracy). [cite: 94]

cases.title: The Genetic Clusters
cases.briefing: 64 cancer cell lines. 6,830 gene expression measurements. No labels provided. We are flying blind.
investigation_points: We cannot predict an output. We must find structure where none is visible. [cite: 118]
Visualizing 6,830 dimensions is impossible. We need dimensionality reduction (PCA) to see the truth. [cite: 121]
Preliminary scans suggest 4 distinct clusters hidden in the noise. [cite: 124]

notation.title: Mathematical Notation
notation.description: Standard symbols and definitions used throughout the text.

entries.definition: The number of variables (features) available for prediction.
entries.example: In the Wage Data, $p = 11$ (Age, Year, Education, etc.).

entries.definition: The value of the j-th variable for the i-th observation.
entries.example: $x_{3,5}$ is the 5th variable of the 3rd patient.

entries.definition: The input matrix of dimensions n x p.
entries.example: The full spreadsheet containing all data points.

entries.definition: The vector of outputs we wish to predict.
entries.example: The column of 'Wages' for all $n$ subjects.

timeline.impact: The earliest form of Linear Regression. First successfully applied to astronomical problems.
Predicted qualitative values (Classes) for the first time, moving beyond simple regression.
An alternative probabilistic approach to classification, now the standard for binary outcomes.
Unified the entire class of statistical learning methods under one mathematical framework.
Computing power allowed for non-linear models, birthing the modern era of decision trees.
